Yes, there have been various initiatives and efforts to address the challenges faced by Cherokee communities in preserving their traditions during the pandemic. 

For instance, the Cherokee Nation Language Program has developed robust online language resources, including virtual language classes, podcasts, videos, and social media pages. These resources help to preserve the Cherokee language and cultural practices and provide an opportunity for people to learn about Cherokee culture from anywhere in the world.

Additionally, several Cherokee communities have adapted their traditional practices to fit within the COVID-19 safety guidelines. For example, some communities have held online versions of powwows and other cultural events, while others have hosted drive-through events to allow people to experience traditional practices from a safe distance.

Furthermore, there have been several funding initiatives to support the preservation of Cherokee culture during the pandemic. For instance, the Cherokee Nation Cultural Tourism Department has provided grants to assist Cherokee artists and small cultural businesses experiencing financial hardship during the pandemic.

Overall, despite the challenges posed by the pandemic, Cherokee communities have demonstrated resilience and innovation in their efforts to preserve their traditions and values.
